final_report.root_cause: The MongoDB server process inside pod url-shorten-mongodb-7fb89b9479-zwhb9 aborts during startup because SSL/TLS initialization fails (fatal assertion in src/mongo/util/net/ssl_manager_openssl.cpp). The container exits with code 14 and repeatedly restarts (CrashLoopBackOff). The failure is caused by a TLS/SSL misconfiguration or invalid/malformed TLS material referenced by mongod (e.g., incorrect file paths in mongod.conf, missing/invalid PEM certificate or key, incorrect permissions or mismatched key/cert), so mongod cannot complete OpenSSL initialization and fassert() aborts the process.
final_report.evidence_summary: Priority #1 investigation: kubectl describe and previous container logs show repeated Terminated states with Exit Code 14, RestartCount >0 and container state Waiting=CrashLoopBackOff. Application logs include a fatal assertion from src/mongo/util/net/ssl_manager_openssl.cpp and an abort after fassert(), indicating mongod failed during SSL/TLS setup. Pod mounts include a ConfigMap (mongod.conf) and a TLS Secret (mongodb-tls), matching the failure mode of bad TLS configuration or invalid cert/key. Priority #2 investigation verified the Kubernetes Service exists and correctly selects the pod, ruling out a missing/misconfigured Service as the root cause.
final_report.investigation_summary: What was done: (1) Priority #1: inspected pod url-shorten-mongodb-7fb89b9479-zwhb9 via kubectl describe and fetched previous container logs; correlated Exit Code 14, CrashLoopBackOff, and fatal OpenSSL assertion in mongod logs to conclude mongod aborts during TLS initialization. (2) Priority #2: validated Service url-shorten-mongodb exists and routes to the pod (ClusterIP 10.96.182.184, port 27017), disproving a Service-level routing/config issue. Conclusion: the failure is application-level (mongod) caused by TLS/SSL initialization error. Recommended immediate remediation: inspect the mounted TLS secret contents (certificate and private key) and mongod.conf TLS file paths/permissions; verify cert/key are valid PEM, key matches cert, and mongod.conf points to correct files. If a recent secret or config change occurred, consider rolling back to the last-working secret/config.
